there's a whole field of people working on Bitcoin R & D and some guys with limited experience want to join in? great, feel free to suggest ideas but dont get upset if they fail peer review, prepare to learn, calm down & adopt tech, hire strong devs - it is open for participation

miners are in a cut-throat business. Bitcoin isnt defined by miners any more than the limits of electronic circuits defined by those mining rare earth elements. they're a needed part, and invested also, but they provide a paid service.

all Bitcoin has to do to win the market, is not fail (in a technology sense) that's what people pay for: permissionless uncensorable transfer with a dependable store of value. scale like lightning & next gen lightning factories, is icing, Bitcoin will win on micropayments also.
and per @petertoddbtc 's point this might have caused a multi-way consensus fork. non-determinism is about the worst-case for bitcoin consensus failure.
it's a slow running group-buy of anti-bitcoiner's bitcoin. this is good - people who want to pivot opt-out and divest.

luckily for Bitcoin, there's so far been a strong correlation between competence & unwillingness to work on contentious forks. by analogy the reason is it is like searching for an artist to deface a Picasso painting with a sledgehammer, even if they were penniless they'd refuse.

Even beyond cash-settled futures, CME Chairman Melamed thinks he can "tame" decentralized crypto and bitcoin markets. https:// twitter.com/jonmatonis/sta tus/931860006055526400 …
Ryan, I don't think the physical-settlement futures will be impossible and Melamed can't possibly believe that cash-settled alone will "tame" the crypto market.

Risks with cash-settled bitcoin futures contract: 1. Price index too easily gamed; 2. No physical commodity (private keys) for integrity of short positions; 3. Maintenance margins approaching 100% so no real leverage during volatility; 4. Limit-up, limit-down insolvency
I know. Cash settled futures market for bitcoin has even greater challenges. Please see second part of my reply.
...and the cash-settled bitcoin contract is a precursor to an exchange offering a proper physical-settlement futures contract. (via @globitex_ )

I think Bitcoin will prove more difficult to tame than Melamed believes. Warehousing, open contract limits, and maintenance margin calcs all behave differently under a digital asset class w/physical settlement.
